Blog.post: It always puzzles me how immigrants change the way our country is when they arrive here. Don't get me wrong, we are all pretty much immigrants in one generation or another. I have a problem with people who come here and complain how it was better where they came from. "Then go back!" I like to say. If it was so good from where they came, then why leave? And why force us to adopt their customs and bend our rules for them? (i.e. Turbans allowed in police uniform, and religious daggers allowed in school) A friend of mine had a great idea. The U.S.A should buy us out by giving each Canadian citizen $1,000,000.00, u.s. of course. We would all be instant millionaires! The Americans seem to have a handle on their patriotism. Immigrants are only too happy to give up their past and call themselves an American. Why are we so different in this regard? Happy 137th Canada! Here is an e-mail I received not too long ago; This says it all! This is an editorial written by a Canadian citizen, published in a Canadian newspaper. He did quite a job; didn't he? Read on, please! IMMIGRANTS, NOT CANADIANS, MUST ADAPT. I'm tired of this nation worrying about whether we are offending some individual or their culture. I'm not against immigration, nor do I hold a grudge against anyone who is seeking a better life by coming to Canada. Our population is almost entirely made up of descendants of immigrants. However, there are a few things that those who have recently come to our country, and apparently some born here, need to understand. This idea of Canada being a multicultural community has served only to dilute our sovereignty and our national identity. As Canadians, we have our own culture, our own society, our own language and our own lifestyle. This culture has been developed over centuries of struggles, trials, and victories by millions of men and women who have sought freedom. We speak ENGLISH and FRENCH, not Spanish, Portuguese, Arabic, Chinese, Japanese, Russian, or any other language. Therefore, if you wish to become part of our society, learn the language! You can still keep yours but learn ours! We have many belief's and religion's and no one belief or religion is worth more or less than the other. That's what makes us so unique. We even have the right not to believe. If you want to participate in your community or belong to a group or organization, It is YOUR responsiblity to adapt to their rules and regulations. Not the other way around. If the Maple Leaf offends you, then you should seriously consider a move to another part of this planet. We are happy with our culture and have no desire to change, and we really don't care how you did things where you came from. We as a country of tax paying citizens should not be paying for you to abuse us with our own immigration laws. If you want to make a lawyer wealthier then do it with YOUR own cash. There should be no discounts or freebee's to immigrants unless we're going to give it to our own unfortunate people too! We'll help guide you, but if there's a cost you have to cover it! This is OUR COUNTRY, our land, and our lifestyle. Our government gives every citizen the right to express his or her opinion and we will allow you every opportunity to do so. But once you are done complaining, whining,and griping about our flag, our pledge, our national motto, or our way of life, I highly encourage you take advantage of one other great Canadian freedom,THE RIGHT TO LEAVE.

I really don't like starting something, like a blog, and not continuing with it. I do have an excuse, whether it's a good one or not, I hope to be blogging full gear soon! Pictures and a short story will follow. Saturday we had Brian and family over for a terrific day at our house, you can read about that on his blog. urlLink http://vv.typepad.com/parsontoperson/2004/07/bbq_hungarian_s.html#comments Thursday we are having Niki's cousin and family over from Georgia. An article in Christianity today writes; Former Labor Secretary Predicts Religious War in America "The true battle will be between modern civilization and anti-modernists; between those who believe in the primacy of the individual and those who believe that human beings owe their allegiance and identity to a higher authority; between those who give priority to life in this world and those who believe that human life is mere preparation for an existence beyond life; between those who believe in science, reason, and logic and those who believe that truth is revealed through Scripture and religious dogma. Terrorism will disrupt and destroy lives. But terrorism itself is not the greatest danger we face." For some time now (several years), I've been thinking that we are going to endure persecution here in North America. With all that is going on in the world, how they call evil good and good evil, this maybe a possibility. Even in such a free state! I also believe God is moving amongst His people and separating the true followers from the superficial ones. Persecution would really be the test.

In regards to our daily life, whether it be at work, home, or school, how much of our own effort do we exert to accomplish a task and how much do we lean on God and let him work things out through faith? What is the balance? In the old testament God gave skill to the workers to perform their work. How much did they have to train/study? If a missionary is called to go to another language/culture, how much effort, preparation, or fund-raising of his own strength should he make before he goes? How much time and energy should we use to provide for our families, like getting a second job, or to seek a higher paying job, to make ends meet, or to pay-off a student loan, and how much do we "seek first the kingdom of God and all these things will be added unto you"?

I have been asked some questions lately, for which I do not have any solid answers. I will be posting a series of topics/questions in order to provide me with a broader base of information and views toward these questions. Does healing still occur? Why haven't I seen any? Can anyone receive the gift of healing if they ask for it? I'm not talking about gradual healing here, but rather instant healing. Here are some verses to fuel the discussion: Matthew 10:1 He called his twelve disciples to him and gave them authority to drive out evil spirits and to heal every disease and sickness. Mark 16: 15He said to them, "Go into all the world and preach the good news to all creation. 16Whoever believes and is baptized will be saved, but whoever does not believe will be condemned. 17And these signs will accompany those who believe: In my name they will drive out demons; they will speak in new tongues; 18they will pick up snakes with their hands; and when they drink deadly poison, it will not hurt them at all; they will place their hands on sick people, and they will get well."

It has been many years since my brother in-law, Benny, came to Canada to visit us. This weekend we had the privilege of having Benny and his girlfriend Emily over for a couple of days. We had a blast staying up late both nights. Of course, it didn't seem so great a few hours later when our four kids woke us up. They took in seeing the CN tower with my wife on Saturday. At night we had a campfire. They promised us they would be back more often in the future. We look forward to that! After they left today, we had a lazy hazy afternoon, with one exception. I took the training wheels off my son's bike preparing to give him a lesson on riding without them. Before I could say something, he bolted away and rode off! We couldn't believe it. I guess it was long over-due. He was so proud of his accomplishment and so were we.

Tonight we had a very nice visit with Brian, Lynn and the kids. They invited us up to the cottage for a BBQ. We (meaning everybody but me) had a nice time swimming in the very shallow, sandy lake in the backyard. If it's not like 85-90 degrees, I'm not interested thank you very much. It's funny where this blogging thing will lead. We met Brian through one of Darryl's blog links, and have gotten to know his family a bit through some visits. The more time we spend together, the more I realize what an awesome family they are, and how easily our 2 families get along. Our combined 6 kids seemed to have a blast, and we adults had a nice time getting to know each other better. It was really exciting hearing and seeing about their Dominican mission's trip. I'm looking forward to spending a lot more time together with them in the future. UPDATE: I finally figured out this "Posted By" business!
